chapter.htmlHeader: Intranasal decongestants

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ephedrine hydrochloride 0.5% nasal drops are licensed for the management of nasal congestion in adults and children aged 12 years and over:
    • For children aged 12–17 years — apply 1–2 drops up to four times a day as required for a maximum of seven days, to be instilled into each nostril.
  • Xylometazoline hydrochloride nasal drops or spray are licensed for the management of nasal congestion in adults and children over 6 years of age, depending on the person's age:
    • For children aged 6–11 years — 1–2 nasal drops applied 1–2 times a day as required for a maximum duration of five days, 0.05% solution to be administered into each nostril.
    • For children aged 12–17 years and adults — 2–3 drops applied 2–3 times a day as required for a maximum duration of seven days, 0.1% solution to be administered into each nostril; or one nasal spray applied 1–3 times a day as required for a maximum duration of seven days, to be administered into each nostril.

[BNF for Children, 2017; BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Contraindications and cautions
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Prescribe intranasal ephedrine and xylometazoline with caution to people with:
    • Diabetes mellitus.
    • Hypertension.
    • Hyperthyroidism.
    • Cardiovascular disease.
    • Angle-closure glaucoma and prostatic hyperplasia or enlargement (risk of acute urinary retention in men) — for xylometazoline hydrochloride.

[BNF for Children, 2017; BNF 76, 2018]

• Possible adverse effects of intranasal ephedrine and xylometazoline include:
    • Long-term use of intranasal decongestants is associated with rebound nasal congestion upon withdrawal, which in turn encourages further use that can result in hypertrophy of the nasal mucosa (so-called 'rhinitis medicamentosa'). In addition, tolerance with diminished effect may be seen after excessive use.
    • Headache, nausea, transient visual disturbances, local irritation and dryness.
    • Hallucinations, restlessness, and sleep disturbance in small children (with xylometazoline hydrochloride use).

[BNF for Children, 2017; BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Drug interactions
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Possible drug interactions with intranasal ephedrine hydrochloride include:
    • The manufacturer advises that prescribers avoid:
    • Amitriptyline — amitriptyline is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Clomipramine — clomipramine is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Dosulepin — dosulepin is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Doxepin — doxepin is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Imipramine — imipramine is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Lofepramine — lofepramine is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Nortriptyline — nortriptyline is predicted to decrease the effects of ephedrine.
    • Rasagiline — rasagiline is predicted to increase the risk of a hypertensive crisis when given with ephedrine.
    • Selegiline — selegiline is predicted to increase the risk of a hypertensive crisis when given with ephedrine.
    • In addition, the manufacturer advises that prescribers avoid the following medications in children:
    • Aminophylline — ephedrine increases the risk of side-effects when given with aminophylline. 
    • Theophylline — ephedrine increases the risk of side-effects when given with theophylline.
  • Possible drug interactions with intranasal xylometazoline hydrochloride include:
    • Rasagiline — rasagiline is predicted to increase the risk of a hypertensive crisis when given with xylometazoline. Manufacturer advises avoid.
    • Selegiline — selegiline is predicted to increase the risk of a hypertensive crisis when given with xylometazoline. Manufacturer advises avoid.

[BNF for Children, 2017; BNF 76, 2018]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Pregnancy and breastfeeding
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Pregnancy

  • The manufacturer advises to avoid the use of intranasal ephedrine and xylometazoline during pregnancy.

Breastfeeding

  • Ephedrine is present in breast milk and the manufacturer advises avoid — irritability and sleep disturbance reported.
  • There is no specific information regarding the safety of intranasal xylometazoline in breastfeeding, and the manufacturer advises caution.

[BNF for Children, 2017; BNF 76, 2018]
